newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgian Caterpillar staff block traffic.
newsitem.headline: Belgian Caterpillar staff block traffic.

text.p: Workers of the Belgian unit of U.S. earth-moving equipment maker Caterpillar, angry about jobs cuts and an austerity plan, on Friday blockaded their plant at Gosselies, south of Brussels, and caused traffic chaos.

From 8 a.m. (0700 GMT) union pickets blocked access roads and entrances to the plant. Employees' cars, unable to reach the Caterpillar carpark, stopped on the N5 Brussels to Charleroi motorway, a Reuters correspondent said.
Workers entered a second day of strike on Friday over management plans to sack 227 mainly young, blue-collar workers and cut planned investment for 1997 by 20 percent.

The company, which has been in an extended struggle with unions to introduce a five-year 1.8 billion franc ($58 million) cost-cutting plan, has said it will re-assess whether to continue what it called non-competitive jobs in Belgium or relocalise them.
The plan aimed at boosting competitiveness includes savings of 370 million francs on wages.
Earlier this month staff rejected the plan in a referendum.
Unions meet on Saturday to decide on further action.
The plant currently employs some 2,500 blue-collar workers and 1,000 white-collar staff.
